Line 25: Line 25:
On 31 January 2011, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' ran an exclusive interview with [[Bashar al-Assad]], [[President]] of [[Syria]], in which he said it's time to reform. In a comment on the protests in [[Protests in Egypt|Egypt]], [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising|Tunisia]] and [[2011 Yemeni protests|Yemen]], he said a "new era" is coming to the [[Middle East]], and that Arab rulers would need to do more to accommodate their people's rising political and economic aspirations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703833204576114712441122894.html |title=Interview With Syrian President Bashar al-Assad |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704832704576114340735033236.html |title=Syria Strongman: Time for 'Reform' |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref> However, president [[Bashar al-Assad|Al-Assad]] has also declared that his state is immune from the kinds of mass protests that have taken place in Egypt.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2011/02/02/middle-east-protests-syria-egypt/ FOX News opinion].</ref>
On 31 January 2011, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' ran an exclusive interview with [[Bashar al-Assad]], [[President]] of [[Syria]], in which he said it's time to reform. In a comment on the protests in [[Protests in Egypt|Egypt]], [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising|Tunisia]] and [[2011 Yemeni protests|Yemen]], he said a "new era" is coming to the [[Middle East]], and that Arab rulers would need to do more to accommodate their people's rising political and economic aspirations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703833204576114712441122894.html |title=Interview With Syrian President Bashar al-Assad |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704832704576114340735033236.html |title=Syria Strongman: Time for 'Reform' |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref> However, president [[Bashar al-Assad|Al-Assad]] has also declared that his state is immune from the kinds of mass protests that have taken place in Egypt.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2011/02/02/middle-east-protests-syria-egypt/ FOX News opinion].</ref>
â
==Timeline==
+
== Protests ===
  +
=== Timeline ===
  +
==== 26-27 January ====
On 26 January 2011, Hasan Ali Akleh from [[Al-Hasakah]] poured gasoline and burned himself in the same way as Mohamed Bouazizi. According to eyewitnesses, the action was "a protest against the [[Syrian government]]".<ref name="Hasan Ali Akleh 1">{{cite web|url=http://www.free-syria.com/loadarticle.php?articleid=37797 |title=Information on the death of a young man who burned himself in Al Hasakah |publisher=free-syria.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref><ref name="Hasan Ali Akleh 2">{{cite web|url=http://www.metransparent.com/spip.php?page=article&id_article=12661&lang=ar |title=Syrian suicider is "Hasan Ali Akleh". Damascus has banned a demonstration in support of Egypt |publisher=metransparent.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref>
On 26 January 2011, Hasan Ali Akleh from [[Al-Hasakah]] poured gasoline and burned himself in the same way as Mohamed Bouazizi. According to eyewitnesses, the action was "a protest against the [[Syrian government]]".<ref name="Hasan Ali Akleh 1">{{cite web|url=http://www.free-syria.com/loadarticle.php?articleid=37797 |title=Information on the death of a young man who burned himself in Al Hasakah |publisher=free-syria.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref><ref name="Hasan Ali Akleh 2">{{cite web|url=http://www.metransparent.com/spip.php?page=article&id_article=12661&lang=ar |title=Syrian suicider is "Hasan Ali Akleh". Damascus has banned a demonstration in support of Egypt |publisher=metransparent.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref>
  +
==== 28 January ====
On 28 January 2011, a demonstration was held in [[Ar-Raqqah]] during the evening, in protest against the killing of two soldiers of [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://free-syria.com/loadarticle.php?articleid=37803 |title=Demonstration in Ar-Raqqa, Syria |publisher=free-syria.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref>
On 28 January 2011, a demonstration was held in [[Ar-Raqqah]] during the evening, in protest against the killing of two soldiers of [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://free-syria.com/loadarticle.php?articleid=37803 |title=Demonstration in Ar-Raqqa, Syria |publisher=free-syria.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-30}}</ref>
  +
==== 3-16 February ====
On 3 February another "Day of rage" was called for in Syria from 4â5 February on [[social media]] sites Facebook and Twitter. Protesters demand reform in the government, however most protests so far have remained outside of Syria and have been small.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41400687/ns/world_news-mideastn_africa/ |title='Day of rage' protest urged in Syria - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aysor.am/en/news/2011/02/03/syrian-facebook-twitter/ |title=âDay of Rageâ planned for Syria; protests scheduled for Feb 4-5 - aysor.am - Hot news from Armenia |publisher=aysor.am |date= |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://freedomist.com/2011/01/30/syran-anger-day-planned-feb-5-2011/|title=Syrian Anger Day Planned Feb 5, 2011|author=William R Collier jr|date=January 30, 2011|publisher=The Freedomist|accessdate=January 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://topsy.com/freedomist.com/2011/01/30/syran-anger-day-planned-feb-5-2011/ |title=Syrian Anger Day Planned Feb 5, 2011 | The Freedomist |publisher=TOPSY |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> The protests were expected to begin on 4 February 2011 as [[social media]] mobilised the people of [[Syria]] for rallies demanding freedom, [[human rights]] and the end to the [[state of emergency]]. Protests were also scheduled for 5 February in front of the parliament in [[Damascus]] and at Syrian embassies internationally.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html "Calls for weekend protests in Syria"].</ref> The only known action took place February 5, where hundreds of protesters in [[Al-Hasakah]] participated in a mass demonstration, calling for the [[Bashar al-Assad| President]]'s departure. Syrian authorities have arrested dozens and the demonstration was triggered quickly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://free-syria.com/loadarticle.php?articleid=37849 |title=Demonstration on the day of anger in Hasaka and Syrian authorities arrested dozens |publisher=free-syria.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-15}}</ref> Suhair Atassi, who runs the banned [[Jamal al-Atassi| Jamal Atassi Forum]], called for political reforms and the reinstatement of civil rights, as well as an end to the emergency law in place since 1963.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/2011/02/201129135657367367.html |title=Q&A: Syrian activist Suhair Atassi |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-02-09 |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> However, no protests occurred on either date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2011/02/04/Syria-quiet-on-day-of-rage/UPI-58781296853501/ |title=Syria quiet on day of rage |publisher=UPI.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0205/1224289070429.html |title=Call for Syrian 'day of rage' as planned protests fail to ignite - The Irish Times - Sat, Feb 05, 2011 |publisher=The Irish Times |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Karam |first=Zeina |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/02/05/2052033/syria-escapes-day-of-rage-protests.html |title=Syria escapes 'Day of Rage' protests - World Wires |publisher=MiamiHerald.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> Though internet services were said to have been curbed, ''Facebook'' and ''Youtube'' were reported to have been restored on 8 February.<ref name="JENNIFER PRESTON"> {{cite news
On 3 February another "Day of rage" was called for in Syria from 4â5 February on [[social media]] sites Facebook and Twitter. Protesters demand reform in the government, however most protests so far have remained outside of Syria and have been small.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41400687/ns/world_news-mideastn_africa/ |title='Day of rage' protest urged in Syria - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aysor.am/en/news/2011/02/03/syrian-facebook-twitter/ |title=âDay of Rageâ planned for Syria; protests scheduled for Feb 4-5 - aysor.am - Hot news from Armenia |publisher=aysor.am |date= |accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://freedomist.com/2011/01/30/syran-anger-day-planned-feb-5-2011/|title=Syrian Anger Day Planned Feb 5, 2011|author=William R Collier jr|date=January 30, 2011|publisher=The Freedomist|accessdate=January 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://topsy.com/freedomist.com/2011/01/30/syran-anger-day-planned-feb-5-2011/ |title=Syrian Anger Day Planned Feb 5, 2011 | The Freedomist |publisher=TOPSY |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref> The protests were expected to begin on 4 February 2011 as [[social media]] mobilised the people of [[Syria]] for rallies demanding freedom, [[human rights]] and the end to the [[state of emergency]]. Protests were also scheduled for 5 February in front of the parliament in [[Damascus]] and at Syrian embassies internationally.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html "Calls for weekend protests in Syria"].</ref> The only known action took place February 5, where hundreds of protesters in [[Al-Hasakah]] participated in a mass demonstration, calling for the [[Bashar al-Assad| President]]'s departure. Syrian authorities have arrested dozens and the demonstration was triggered quickly.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://free-syria.com/loadarticle.php?articleid=37849 |title=Demonstration on the day of anger in Hasaka and Syrian authorities arrested dozens |publisher=free-syria.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-15}}</ref> Suhair Atassi, who runs the banned [[Jamal al-Atassi| Jamal Atassi Forum]], called for political reforms and the reinstatement of civil rights, as well as an end to the emergency law in place since 1963.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/2011/02/201129135657367367.html |title=Q&A: Syrian activist Suhair Atassi |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-02-09 |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> However, no protests occurred on either date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2011/02/04/Syria-quiet-on-day-of-rage/UPI-58781296853501/ |title=Syria quiet on day of rage |publisher=UPI.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0205/1224289070429.html |title=Call for Syrian 'day of rage' as planned protests fail to ignite - The Irish Times - Sat, Feb 05, 2011 |publisher=The Irish Times |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Karam |first=Zeina |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/02/05/2052033/syria-escapes-day-of-rage-protests.html |title=Syria escapes 'Day of Rage' protests - World Wires |publisher=MiamiHerald.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> Though internet services were said to have been curbed, ''Facebook'' and ''Youtube'' were reported to have been restored on 8 February.<ref name="JENNIFER PRESTON"> {{cite news
| last= PRESTON

| accessdate= }} </ref> Suggestions were made that easing the ban could be a way to track activists.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jillian York |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/02/2011212122746819907.html |title=Unblocking Syria's social media |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> After the failure of attempts to a "day of rage," ''[[Al Jazeera]]'' called the country "a kingdom of silence" and identified key factors for stability within Syria as being strict security measures, the popularity of President [[Bashar al-Assad]], and fears of potential sectarian violence in the aftermath of a government ouster (akin to neighbouring [[Iraqi insurgency|Iraq]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/02/201129103121562395.html |title=Syria: 'A kingdom of silence' |publisher=aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
  +
==== 17 February ====
  +
{{External media
  +
| video1 = {{YouTube|8Cwm5Ck2sSs|Protests in Damscus, Syria, February 17, 2011}}
  +
}}
On February 17, a fight took place in central [[Damascus]], between a shop owner and traffic police. Everything took a new turn when three police officers began attacking the man and beat him severely. Several people gathered around and blocked the road, while shouting "the [[Syrian people]] will not be pushed down". An eyewitness estimated the number to more than 1,500 demonstrators. [[Secret police]] officers arrived quickly to the scene along with several government officials and finally Minister of the Interior who dispersed the demonstrators.<ref name="ROBERT MACKEY"> {{cite news
On February 17, a fight took place in central [[Damascus]], between a shop owner and traffic police. Everything took a new turn when three police officers began attacking the man and beat him severely. Several people gathered around and blocked the road, while shouting "the [[Syrian people]] will not be pushed down". An eyewitness estimated the number to more than 1,500 demonstrators. [[Secret police]] officers arrived quickly to the scene along with several government officials and finally Minister of the Interior who dispersed the demonstrators.<ref name="ROBERT MACKEY"> {{cite news

On February 19, several Syrian websites reported widespread anti-government [[graffiti]] across Damascus and other major cities.<ref name="sooryoon exclusive"> {{cite web

==== 22 February ====
On 22 February, 14 people were arrested and several more beaten by uniformed and plainclothes police following a peaceful sit-in outside the Libyan embassy in Damascus.<ref name=guardian240211> {{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/24/syria-crackdown-protest-arrests-beatings| title=Syria clamps down on dissent with beatings and arrests| publisher=The Guardian| date=24 February 2011| accessdate=24 February 2011 }} </ref> On 23 February a demonstration in Damascus was violently dispersed, amid increasing reports of intimidation in the wake of unrest in neighbouring Arab countries.<ref name=guardian240211/>
On 22 February, 14 people were arrested and several more beaten by uniformed and plainclothes police following a peaceful sit-in outside the Libyan embassy in Damascus.<ref name=guardian240211> {{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/24/syria-crackdown-protest-arrests-beatings| title=Syria clamps down on dissent with beatings and arrests| publisher=The Guardian| date=24 February 2011| accessdate=24 February 2011 }} </ref> On 23 February a demonstration in Damascus was violently dispersed, amid increasing reports of intimidation in the wake of unrest in neighbouring Arab countries.<ref name=guardian240211/>

==== 23 February ====
  +
On February 23, attempted a professor at the highly screened [[University of Damascus]] start a revolt from within the University facilities, but he was met quickly by security police officers who beat him bloody while screaming at him "Do you want to teach? First, learn that al-Assad family are your masters, you child of a whore". The professor was thereafter taken by intelligence men. A short video from the event spread to different websites.<ref> {{cite web
| url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6GnOa371_Eg
| url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6GnOa371_Eg
| title=Syrian intelligence men

}} </ref>
}} </ref>

==== 24 February ====
On February 24, a new date for a Syrian "day of rage" was announced on March 15 under the name "the Syrian uprising".<ref> {{cite web
